STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 13, 2025
Chad Ulferts
Wayne County DHHS South Central
1801 E Canfield St.
Detroit, MI, 48207-4635
RE: License#: CP820201496
Dear Mr. Ulferts:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/19/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP820201496
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Chad Ulferts
Name of Agency: WAYNE COUNTY DHHS - SOUTHCENTRAL
Agency Address: 1801 E CANFIELD ST
DETROIT, MI 48207-4635
Agency Telephone #: 3135785102
Original Issuance Date: 09/03/1993
Service Types: Place children in foster home, Supervise
Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
Five of 22 personnel records reviewed showed the employee's evaluations were
not completed timely. Four of the five 3-month probationary evaluation was not
completed timely; and one annual evaluation was not timely in the fifth record.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal December 2024, CAP approved 4/23/2025.
Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:

(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed where the child was replaced
the record did not show proof the caregiver was provided all known information
about the child prior to placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal December 2024, CAP approved 4/23/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s 9-month
dental exam was due by 6/26/2025; and it was completed late on 8/18/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a
behavioral/mental health and trauma screening, within
30 calendar days from the date the child entered into
an out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of
the last physical examination.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's medical was
due on 1/8/2025; and it was completed late on 1/14/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:

Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(e) A dental examination must be completed within 3
months before entry into foster care or an initial dental
examination must be completed not more than 90
calendar days after entry into a foster care out-of-home
placement. A child entering foster care under 1 year of
age must have an initial dental exam within 3 months of
his or her first birthday.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the respective child's
dental examination due 10/16/2024, 3/9/2025 and 8/25/2025, were completed on
5/15/2025, 4/7/2025; and pendng respectively, was not completed timely, per the
rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal December 2024, CAP approved 4/23/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the
home.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child’s initial service
plan which was due by 1/8/2025 was completed 16 days late on 1/16/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
In two of eight open foster child records reviewed, one record showed the child
had two late updated service plans which were late by 1 and 12 days late
respective. The second child's record showed the child's update service plan was
19 days late.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
In three of eight open foster child records reviewed the respective child’s record
did not show that all treatments plans were reviewed and signed timely by all
parties.
Repeat Violation Estalished:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 4/23/2025.
Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).

One of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the placement selection criteria in the child's initial service plan.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 4/23/2025.
Interim February 2024, CAP approved 4/19/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12213 Record Management.
(1)An agency shall do all the following with respect to
maintenance of required records
(c) Store and maintain each record in a manner to
ensure confidentiality and to prevent unauthorized
access.
A large number of closed foster care and adoption files that have been sent over
from various child placing agencies to this departmental office were seen onsite;
and a large number of these files were not stored in a secured/locked area. The
agency reported it is actively working on better compilation and storage of these
records.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12417(1)(g) Foster parent information: The agency was apprised it
shall clearly and consistently document circumstances leading to placement
related to a child's placement of replacement.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12418(6) Development of service plans: The agency was advised
best practice would be to cross out and initial a mistake as opposed to using
white out.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance

The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period.
The first correction action plan related to the agency’s December 2024 Renewal
inspection, completed on 12/27/2024 where the CAP was approved on 4/23/2025.
During that inspection the agency received 28 rule violations; of which 14 were
repeat violations. Twelve of the 28 citations were ones where 4 to 8 individual
cases were found in violation for various specific rules; and that inspection’s
findings resulted in the agency’s current provisional license.
During this 2025 Renewal inspection, the agency received 10 rule violations, and
though 9 are repeat violations, the agency implemented its corrective action plan
and made significant progress and improvements. 7 of the 9 violations were
previously cited during the February 2024 Interim inspection and 5 of the 9
violations were previously cited during the December 2024 Renewal inspection. Of
the 5 repeat violations from the December 2024 Renewal inspection, the number
of cases cited decreased for 2 rules cited, remained the same for 2 rules cited and
a slight increase for one rule cited. In 2024 8 of 8 individual child records were
cited decreasing to 3 of 8 related to Development of service plans during this
inspection. In 2024 4 of 8 individual records were cited decreasing to 1 of 8 related
to the Initial service plans during this inspection. The number of cases impacted
that remained the same, were 3 of 8 related Medical and dental policy rule; and 1
of 8 related to a Change of placement rule. There was a slight increase from 19.6
to 22% for employee performance noncompliance. It is also noted that the
Placement rule; Foster Parent Information rule; and the Development of service
plans rule pertaining to worker and supervisor signatures, which the agency had
significant difficulty with during the 2024 Renewal inspection, the agency was in
compliance with these rule during this inspection. The agency reported it had
regular and ongoing reviews, and discussions on how to make progress on this
corrective plan; and the progress was illustrated per this inspection.
The second corrective action plan was related to special Investigation
2025SIC000332 initiated 1/27/2025 that alleged a foster care worker threatened
and fought with a foster youth after the youth called them a name. The agency
was found in noncompliance after interviews as well as video evidence showed
the foster care worker engaged in a physical altercation with the youth. There was
no evidence to support the foster care worker’s report that they acted in self-
defense. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that was
approved on 3/31/2025; which included the foster worker’s separation from the
agency, supervisory shadowing of workers in the community, and mandatory de-
escalation training for all staff. The agency’s corrective action plan remains active,
and the agency is complying with it.
The third corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2025SIC0000411
initiated 2/28/2025, related to an allegation that the agency placed a youth in
another agency’s foster home without notifying the agency; and that action put the
foster home over the home’s approved licensing capacity. The investigation found

the agency in noncompliance of the borrowed home rule. Despite some confusion
due to who was in communication with whom; no communication occurred with
the agency’s licensing department or the foster home’s certifying agency’s
licensing department to ensure appropriate borrowed bed forms were completed
prior to the child’s placement. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective
action plan that was approved on 4/18/2025. The corrective action plan included
all foster care workers and supervisor’s reviewing the borrowed home rules; and
foster care workers and children protective service staff reviewing and completing
a borrowed bed agreement prior to placement of a child in another agency’s foster
home. The agency’s corrective action plan remains active, and the agency is
complying with it.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 8/28/2025. The chief
administrator (CA) reported on the prior year's violations, and the action steps it
put in place to achieve compliance. The CA indicated all aspects of the corrective
action plan were adhered to, monitored, reviewed, and followed up on to achieve
and maintain compliance. Foster care workers and supervisors consistently used
the reports that are available from both the Data Warehouse and their individual
Book of Business to monitor compliance of foster care Key Performance Indicators
(KPI). Additionally, workers and supervisors had additional support from the
agency’s MiTEAM Quality Assurance Analysts and training throughout the year.
Furthermore, all staff hires, training, and performance review dates are monitored
on a spreadsheet; where reminders and follow-up are ongoing to ensure
completion and documentation is received. The CA also reported that the
agency’s foster care caseloads are monitored weekly to maintain prescribed
caseload compliance.
The agency noted they have monthly case conferences, and supervisors, section
managers, the CA and quality assurance analysts conduct monthly KPI meetings
with the foster care units to discuss performance and policy compliance amongst
its strengths. The agency reported it shall continue all efforts to improve and
achieve ongoing rule compliance.
Financial Overview
Not applicable.
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the current chief administrator, section manager,
administrative assistant and other administrative staff, three foster workers and
one supervisor was interviewed. The staff interviewed reported numerous
strengths and positives attributes for the agency; which included, management
listening to them; support from their immediate supervisor and other supervisors;
staff being passionate about their jobs and promoting and listening to parents;
chief administrator holding staff responsible keeping staff abreast of the agency’s
progress or lack thereof; chief administrator open door policy, working with staff to
improve, CA celebrating staff; and improved staff morale. As for areas of

improvement needed, staff reported a desire for more program, and task specific
trainings (i.e. placement changes, accessing resources for families); training on
how to navigate MISACWIS; having a lead worker to help guide and train new
staff; ways to train families on how to access resources themselves; and more
building safety protocol for the security of all staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
My walk through in the agency's office showed the agency has sufficient space
and equipment for its staff. The agency has gone paperless, and so current
records are electronic files, and closed paper files are properly stored. A large
number of closed foster care and adoption files that have been sent over from
various child placing agencies to this departmental office were seen onsite; and a
large number of these files were not stored in a secured/locked area as cited
above.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two safety alerts identified.
Safety Alert #1: There were no operable smoke detector on the second floor of the
home and no operable carbon monoxide detector in the home. Three of the children
are sleeping in the basement. A broken bunk bed, full size bed, and a crib was
observed. The basement does not have egress windows.
Resolution: On 9/12/2025 the agency staff installed two new smoke/carbon
monoxide combination detectors, one on each level of the home. Photos were
attached showing the detectors installed. The agency advised the caregiver had
reported the foster children were sleeping in the two upstairs beds. On 9/4/2025 the
caregiver and mother reported the children’s beds had been broken; and
replacements were needed. The agency purchased new beds and provided them on
9/6/2025; however, the beds had not been assembled by the caregiver or mother.
On 9/12/2025 the agency staff assembled the children’s beds in the designated
upstairs bedrooms. Photographs were provided showing the beds in place.
Additionally, a written safety plan was completed with the family related to it being
mandatory for the children to sleep upstairs. A copy of the safety plan was
provided.
Safety Alert # 2: There were no operable carbon monoxide detector in the home.
Resolution: The agency reported during home visit on 08/11/2025 a combination
smoke/carbon monoxide detector had been observed in the home. Additionally, the
agency reported after receiving this safety alert on 9/16/2025 their staff learned from
the caregiver that the carbon monoxide detector was no longer present in the home
due to the caregiver removing it because it activated while they were cooking. On
9/16/2025 agency staff conducted a follow-up visit with the family and installed a
new combination detector. A safety plan was also developed with the family. A photo

showing that the smoke/carbon monoxide detector was installed, was provided,
along with a copy of the safety plan.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
September 19, 2025
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 19, 2025

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
